The Middle English Dictionary defines debonair as “kindly, mercifully; courteously, graciously; humbly, modestly.” One need not assume the word carries modern connotations of urbanity for it nonetheless to characterize the Pearl Maiden inappropriately, if she is indeed an infant. Infants express a rather limited range of attitudes and emotions and cannot properly embody any of the range of characteristics contained within the semantic field of debonair

title: In his treatise on courtly love, Andreas Capellanus rejects rape as inappropriate behavior for a knight: “That which a lover takes against the will of his beloved has no relish” (The Art of Courtly Love

Of course, Andreas’s highly ironic tone often makes deciphering his meaning difficult, but one need only remember Chaucer’s Wife of Bath’s Tale to see the ways in which rape fractures a courtly construction of appropriate knightly masculinity

The author of Eger and Grime repeatedly delays identifying characters by name, a fairly common trope of medieval romance (as in Chrétien de Troyes’s Lancelot). Grey Steele is not named until line 345, after he has defeated Eger. Loosepine is not named until line 1406, when she marries Grime

the narratival reticence to name characters builds suspense, but it also underscores the ways in which characters are constructed through their relationships—whether combative or nurturing—to Eger’s and Grime’s masculinities
The Trouble with Normal: Sex, Politics, and the Ethics of Queer Life

In medieval romance, the need for a son to inherit his family’s estate and to continue the family dynasty often casts daughters in the position of unwanted or problematic heirs. For example, this cultural preference for sons catalyzes Silence’s transvestism in Roman de Silence. Studies of the connection between Roman de Silence and patriarchal inheritance customs include Christopher Callahan, “Canon Law, Primogeniture, and the Marriage of Ebain and Silence
